Okay, so we've implemented Double Pole Balancing and DPB with no
velocities=
 input into the network.  And ANJI is solving them fine,
with both Ken's mu=
tation operators and with ours.  We haven't quite
implemented the No Wiggli=
ng penalty, but are about to do that.

One question we had was this: Were a=
ll experiments with double pole
balancing started from the same, determinis=
tic state?  That is, with
one pole at 0 degrees (upright), and the other le=
aning at exactly 1
degree?

Since we hadn't implemented the domain before, =
we hadn't really
thought about it much, but wouldn't it be fairly easy to s=
cale up the
difficulty of this domain by randomizing the initial starting
c=
onditions?  That is, have the poles start at random initial
positions?

If =
we're evolving a controller, this thing would be extremely brittle
if it on=
ly learned to balance poles from a single starting position,
wouldn't it?

=
By extension, the initial cart position could also be randomized.  The
cont=
rollers could be given a small amount of noise.  There could also
be "wind"=
 or some other sort of noise added to the system to scale up
difficulty.

I=
s anyone aware of this being done with any of the previous pole
balancing w=
ork?  If not, why?

Derek
